trends: There have been 4 other sightings in Enumclaw
There were no other sightings in Enumclaw on or around July 4th 2010
Summary: Three amber colored fireballs which slowly floated across the sky in a three minute period.
divs: sighting detailson the night of july 4th, 2010 at approximatly 2220 hours pacific, myself and three others witnessed three amber colored fireballs float across the sky from the town of enumclaw in washington state. the estimated time of the sighting is based off of having just returned from a local city fireworks show which ended at 2205. as we were unloading the truck back at my friends house, which is in a rural part of the county consisting of mostly farms, about five miles directly west of the downtown part of enumclaw, i noticed an amber\orangish light floating across the sky. i was facing north and saw this first light traveling from west to east at about fifty degrees off the horizon. the first thing that seemed unusual about it was the color. i have lots of experience in aviation and it is unusual to see a single colored light not accompanied by other white or strobing lights. this light seemed to flicker slightly, as though it was a ball on fire from the inside, but not trailing sparks or flames of any kind. there was no noise accompanying the light such as what you would normaly hear from a general aviation or commercial aircraft. the weather at the time is included below, and limits the object to travel under 3,000 feet in altitude such that if it were a ga or commercial aircraft you would be able to hear the engine from our location. i called to my friends and pointed the light out to them after watching it for about 30 seconds. after watching for a few seconds one friend pointed out a second light that had just appeared from the east side of the sky, also traveling west but a few degrees higher off the horizon than the first. by this time the first light, about a minute into the sighting and now to the northeast in the sky suddenly dimmed and disapeared. the second light also dimmed and dissapeared in the northeast about 45 seconds after it was first seen. the third light was noticed right as the second was fading, this one travling from the north, up from the horizon, towards the northeast. this third light at first appeared to be a firework being launched from a field in the distance where a small display was going on, but continued higher and higher and it became obvious that it was not a firework. it arched its way up and about twenty degrees off the horizon began to weave slightly before disapearing 30 seconds later in about the same spot as the two others. all three sightings occured withing the period of three minutes time. we continued to watch the sky for a couple minutes longer but saw no more objects. i remained alert throughout the rest of the night before heading inside around 0030 local time and noticed the white landing lights and strobes as well as the red and green wingtip lights of ga and commercial aircraft but saw no more amber\orange lights in the sky. the only cameras that any of us had with us were cell phone cameras, which i attempted to capture an image with but was unable to get anything other than black sky and will not waste time uploading to this report as there was no evidence after reviewing. in reveiwing the sighting with my friends, the lights seemed very reminicent of watching the iss travel across the sky. the lights all appeared to be of similar size and brightness as the iss, but a much more orangeish\amberish color. due to the weather at the time of the sighting, any possibility of these being planets, satellites or any other high altitude objects was ruled out among us. chinese lanterns were considered but wind patterns were not in favor of that possibility. noaa nws history shows the weather at 2210 on july 4th to be winds west\southwest at 7 miles per hour. clouds were few at 1,700 feet, broken at 2,600 feet and overcast at 3,200 feet with visabiliy 10 miles. weather at 2230 was winds west\southwest at 7 miles per hour. clouds were overcast at 3,000 feet, visabiliy 10 miles.
